security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-only skill containing documentation about REST API design best practices. No executable code, network calls, file system access, or external commands are present.

content.user_title: Design REST APIs with best practices
content.value_statement: APIs often suffer from inconsistent naming, poor URL structure, and incorrect HTTP method usage. This skill provides clear guidelines for designing APIs that are intuitive, scalable, and easy to maintain.
actual_capabilities: Guides URL structure using nouns instead of verbs
Defines proper HTTP method usage (GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE)
Specifies consistent JSON response formats for success and error cases
Recommends appropriate HTTP status codes for different scenarios
Addresses API versioning, authentication, and rate limiting
limitations: Does not generate code implementations for API endpoints
Does not validate existing API designs against the guidelines
Does not create OpenAPI specifications or documentation files
Focused on REST APIs only, not GraphQL or gRPC

use_cases.title: Design new REST APIs
use_cases.description: Apply best practices when designing new REST endpoints to ensure consistency and usability.

use_cases.title: Review existing APIs
use_cases.description: Validate current API designs against industry standards and identify improvement areas.

use_cases.title: Create API style guides
use_cases.description: Establish team-wide conventions for URL naming, response formats, and error handling.

prompt_templates.title: New endpoint design
prompt_templates.scenario: Designing a new user management endpoint
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a REST endpoint for user management. Include the URL structure, HTTP method, request body format, response format, and appropriate status codes.

prompt_templates.title: Error handling
prompt_templates.prompt: What is the proper way to structure error responses in a REST API? Show examples for validation errors, authentication failures, and not found scenarios.

prompt_templates.title: Collection pagination
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a REST API for paginated collections. Show both offset-based and cursor-based pagination approaches with request and response examples.

prompt_templates.title: API versioning
prompt_templates.prompt: What are the best practices for API versioning? Compare URL path versioning versus header-based versioning. When should each approach be used?

output_examples.input: Design a REST endpoint to create and retrieve orders
output: POST /orders - Create a new order (returns 201 Created with Location header)
GET /orders?status=pending&sort=-createdAt - List orders with filtering and sorting
GET /orders/{id} - Retrieve a specific order (returns 404 if not found)
All responses use envelope format with 'data' and 'meta' fields

best_practices: Use plural nouns for resource URLs (e.g., /users not /user)
Apply HTTP methods correctly: GET for reads, POST for creates, PUT for replacements, PATCH for partial updates, DELETE for removals
Structure responses consistently with envelope format including metadata for collections
anti_patterns: Avoid verbs in URLs (e.g., /getUsers, /createOrder) - HTTP method conveys the action
Do not use inconsistent naming conventions like mixing snake_case and camelCase in the same API
Avoid deep nesting beyond two levels - flatten resource hierarchies when possible

faq.question: Which HTTP status codes should I use for errors?
faq.answer: Use 4xx codes for client errors (400 bad request, 401 unauthorized, 403 forbidden, 404 not found, 409 conflict) and 5xx codes for server errors (500, 502, 503, 504).

faq.question: What is the difference between PUT and PATCH?
faq.answer: PUT replaces an entire resource while PATCH performs a partial update. PUT is idempotent and expects a full resource representation.

faq.question: Should I use offset or cursor-based pagination?
faq.answer: Use cursor-based pagination for large datasets and real-time data. Use offset-based for simpler implementations with predictable dataset sizes.

faq.question: How should I handle API authentication?
faq.answer: Prefer Bearer tokens in the Authorization header for most cases. Use API keys in X-API-Key header rather than query parameters for better security.

faq.question: Does this skill support GraphQL or gRPC?
faq.answer: No, this skill focuses exclusively on REST API design principles. GraphQL and gRPC have their own design patterns and conventions.

faq.question: How do I prevent breaking changes in my API?
faq.answer: Version your API from the start. Use URL path versioning (e.g., /v1/users) for major changes. Maintain backward compatibility within each version.
